title: On 1 September 2020, how many states will report a COVID-19 positivity rate greater than 10.0%?
preds: Performed a Monte Carlo simulation of changes in daily positivity rate using bootstrap sampling on an exponentially time-weighted distribution (recent % changes are more likely to be sampled than changes in the far past, with probabilities determined by an exponential distribution).  Calculating 7-day rolling averages of positivity rate based on these results, there is a 0.003% probability of 16 or more states having a >10% positivity rate, with the remaining probability being in the 11-15 states bucket.

There are 14 states with a positivity rate greater than 10.0%. There are 3 other states that are above 9.0% but below 10.0%, but with an increasing trend in the past 14 days: Oklahoma, Minnesota, and Arkansas.  Although these 3 states show increasing COVID rates, I do not expect them to reach the 10% positivity rate threshold on September 1st, because their positivity rates are all below 9.5%.  Still, I determined that because of their generally poor performance in key measures, I should assign a 1% probability that they would reach the 10% level.

Update based on 8/31 data, with 14 states currently above 10%: extremely low probability of sinking to the 6-10 bucket. Confidence still remains extremely high for 11-15, based on the simulations that went into yesterday's forecast, as well as a final assessment of the numbers that will be contributing to tomorrow's 7-day rolling COVID+ average rate in the states near the 10% border.
8/31 data out. All 7 data points that will be included in final settlement point to 100% probability for 11-15 outcome. 1% assigned for any data issue within the COVID Tracking project (e.g. SC)

In order to leave the 11-15 bracket, one of two scenarios must oiccur. 1. 4 states would require their positivity rate to increase by ~50% for the next 2 days. Even if there was a (generous) 10% chance of this happening for each of the 4 states the probability would be << 1%  This is so unlikely that I treat it as 0%. 2. Two states go below 10%. The lowest two states have averages of 11.2 and 12.65. In order for these states to cross below the 10% bracket, they would need two consecutive days with reductions of ~50%. Again this is extremely unlikely I estimate <10% for each state so the likelihood of this scenario can be rounded to 0. Also even of either of these extreme scenarios were to occur, it also requires that no state swings the other way. ie. if two states go below 10%, one state may climb above 10% and it remains in the 11-15 bracket

I did a monte carlo simulation using the data up to 08-30. I took the mean and standard deviation of the daily rate changes from the last two weeks and simulated a one day change from 08-30's data to 08-31. I took the resulting distribution which settled nearly 99.97% into the 11-15 bucket. The monte carlo simulation has a few assumptions:
1. the past is predictive of the future, that the daily percent changes from the past are similar for Sunday to Monday
2. the daily percent changes are roughly normally distributed Barring any major idiosyncratic changes, I believe the simulation gives a very strong prediction for today's eventual results. Of course, the simulation is only as good as the quality of the data.

Intuition Considering that the data point in question is based on a 7 day rolling average, and that we currently have 5 of those days in the data, intuitively I would not expect much of a difference in state’s positivity rates between now and Tuesday. That being said, before analyzing the data, I did not know how large daily changes in the positivity rate could end up being, Methodology First, after downloading the underlying data from COVIDTracking.com, I was able to recreate the positivity rates shown on covidexitstrategy.org by taking the rolling 7 day sum of positiveIncrease divided by totalTestResultIncrease. From this data, I constructed a time seri¬es per state of the positivity rate. Next, for analysis, I isolated data from July 1st, to August 29th, which at the time of writing is the most recently available data. This was an assumption based on the following rationale; (1) By July most states had implemented policies around coronavirus spread prevention, which would not have been as evident in early months in the crisis such as April, (2) the amount of testing done in more recent months would more accurately represent the number of testing we can expect over this week. On this subset of data, the daily standard deviation for each state was computed. After this was done, I wanted to decrease my universe of states to only include likely candidates to have a greater than 0.10% positivity rate. All states that were already above 0.10 made my new subset. Further, any states that were currently below 0.10, but within 2 daily standard deviations away from the 0.10 threshold, were added to the list.  Using this criteria, I end up with 27 states. The final step I did was to run a monte carlo simulation whereby for each state, I draw a random samples from a normal distribution of mean 0, and standard deviation corresponding to that state’s standard deviation of daily changes in the positivity rate. These values were added to the latest positivity rate known on August 29th to predict the future positivity rate. This process was repeated 100,000 times after which the distribution of the number of states in the following categories; 6 to 11, 11 to 15, and 16-20.  Further Improvements Most of the improvements I would make in regards to my analysis revolve around the various assumptions I made. First, the date range I used for analysis, July to August 29th, was based purely off of intuition and my observations from following news around the covid-19 crisis. An improvement to this assumption would be to gather the exact dates where states implemented their covid policies, and add some time lag to these dates to account for the time it takes for these policies to start impacting results. Secondly, I assumed that states which were more than two standard deviations below the threshold were unlikely candidates, however, the assumption here was that the daily change in positivity rates was normally distributed – implying that a two standard deviation was quite unlikely. This assumption might be false, and a proper analysis of the daily changes can engender a more insightful distribution. This assumption flowed over to my monte carlo simulation where I drew random data points from a random distribution.  As a next step, I will update my predictions with the latest data on the 31st.

Running Monte Carlo simulations based on the distribution of daily %positive changes for each state in the past few weeks yields overwhelmingly confident results for the 11-15 bucket. This is the case when sampling from a normal distribution for daily change, as well as when sampling from distributions with fatter tails/higher kurtosis (e.g. Cauchy or Laplace). Simulations in this case seem to line up well with the intuitive answer - with 13 states currently above 10% and only a couple of days remaining, a prior distribution with very high confidence in the 11-15 bucket would be reasonable. The simulations bear this out and in fact yield even higher-confidence results than my initial intuition, which placed about 95% weight on the 11-15 bucket. I used two methods to make this forecast.  1) For each state, I fit a normal distribution to the daily changes in the positivity rate (in order to allow for trends) over the past two weeks. Then, for each state, I sampled from the distribution to produce a few thousand simulated outcomes.  2) I feared that a normal distribution might underestimate tail risk, so I instead took a bootstrapping approach. For each state, I sampled two days of positivity rate changes from the previous two weeks. I also tried sampling across states (meaning that tomorrow's simulated positivity rate change could be a historical change from another state).  For each of these methods, I also tried using percent changes in the positivity rate as opposed to absolute changes. I also broke down the daily changes in the positivity rate into a national trend and state specific trends, as I was concerned that the methods above might underestimate the variance in the outcome by assuming each state's positivity rate changed independently. However, these did not produce significantly different results.  My simulations suggested that the 11-15 probability might be a bit higher than 95%, but I underweighted my forecast because there is additional uncertainty in testing results early in the week. Generally speaking, weekend data is of lower quality, so the recent positivity rates are slightly weaker-than-normal predictors of future rates. While this has not occurred as frequently during the past two weeks, there have been several precipitous drops in the positivity rate, so a sub 11 outcome is not out of the question. On the other hand, there is usually a backlog of cases after the weekend, which can increase the positivity early in the week.

I am underweighting my estimate a little bit by considering the possibility of a backlog of tests over the weekend that will be processed Monday, leading to a jump in cases.
The current data and group consensus show that there's very little variance left.

Since we're predicting the published metrics by this third-party site, the first step is to understand the calculation methodology. We see that it says: "This metric calculates how many positive cases have been surfaced from testing: [Positive Cases / Total Tests]. This metric looks at the rolling average of the past 7 days." Understanding this definition, our second step is to come up with a baseline, high-level estimate. The definition means that the majority of the data used in the calculation is already released. We can get a feel for the likelihood of the last two days of data significantly affecting the final published metric by examining the std of the daily data. New data of a sufficiently large magnitude to affect the final metric is extremely unlikely (values available upon request). Thus, our starting point should be to check how many states currently fulfill the criterion, which is 13. Our next step is to make adjustments. Most states are not even close to the 10% threshold, both to the upside and to the downside. I went through the list and manually assigned tiers to each state based on the likelihood that it would flip. Only 3 states in my analysis were even within striking distance of flipping based on historical variance, 2 with potential to flip upwards and 1 with potential to flip downwards. Based on this, we gauge a very high probability that we land in the 11-15 range, and small tails to 16-20 and 6-10. Note that we would assign a larger value to the upside tail given our characterization of the states. Finally, we construct concrete values. We deliver fat estimates for the tails both as a hedge against overconfidence and for game-theoretical reasons. Since we are not allowed to input fractional percent, we assign 1% to the lower tail and 3% to the upper tail. We assign the rest of the mass to our 11-15 range. Note that we could have done more in depth analysis by modeling the historical variance of each state. However, this is prone to overfitting, and evaluated on a scale that incorporates time vs. accuracy, I believe the above methodology provides a reasonable compromise between the two.

I calculated each state's COVID positivity rate based on a linear forecasted positive case count per state and each state's 7-day average count of conducted tests. Based on this, there are 12 states with projected positivity rates > 10%.  However, I individually analyzed positivity rates for states following clearly non-linear trends (r-values of <0.5 or >-0.5). Of these states, only 4 of them (Alabama, Hawaii, Oklahoma, Utah) have projected positivity rates close to the 10% threshold, with all of them being under the threshold. All 4 of them would have to pass the threshold to bring the total count of states with >10% positivity to the 16-20 bucket (fairly small probability).  Timeseries regression isn't the ideal forecasting method given the high variance in a 14-day data sample and that predictions are given as a probability distribution. This is a placeholder prediction until I can run a Monte Carlo simulation to get a better idea of tails.

went through Johns Hopkins individual states data (this seems to be what covidexitstrategy uses but more up to date) and ballparked the % chance that each state would be over 10% positivity rate. I took a sum of these to get my estimate and adjusted all estimates by plus/minus 20% to get a feel for a confidence interval. Mean estimate was 14.09 and my bounds were 11.28, 15.29.

The first obvious thing to observe is that we are forecasting/looking forward a very short period of time. Today's observed value of number of states w/ positivity >=10% (denote NUM_STATES) is a very strong forecast for tomorrow's NUM_STATES (there is a limited amount of variance left to be realized over the course of the next day). Therefore, it seemed unintuitive to try to fit a sophisticated logarithmic model or time series regression looking back historically over a significant period of time for a couple of reasons. 1.) The variance in our model prediction may far exceed the amount of variance remaining before the settlement date 2.) The most recent "moves" in the Covid positivity rate by day are intuitively a better prediction of tomorrow's move (historical moves looking back across a longer time may not be a good reference point for this). Thus, I will be looking at moves over the course of the last 10 days, and discount moves prior to that as a poor sample for our population parameter (today's move). Important to note: there is a trade-off here between sample size and representativeness of our sample. Last week's moves may better predict tomorrow's move better than last month's moves, but you will be drawing from a smaller sample and thus have greater variance. I pulled the data and calculated the mean change in positivity rate as well as the std dev (volatility) of the change in positivity rate over 1 day. We can then run a simple monte carlo calculation (today's positivity rate + sampled change in positivity rate), sampling from some distribution with parameters mean/std dev mentioned above. The most obvious choice of distribution might be a normal distribution (i.e. assume our one day change is normally distributed). This would result in a 100% chance of being in the 11-15 bucket. However, I believe that this choice of distribution discounts the probability of 'tail events', so I want to account for kurtosis as well. This analysis results in the prediction above.
2 period Monte Carlo with various lookback periods and artificially fat tails for sensitivity analysis. Even with fat tails, probability of realized between 6-10 and 16-20 is estimated to be <1%

Methodology: To construct our predictions for this question, first, we defined a benchmark based on historical values. Subsequently, tried to both support and contradict our initial hypothesis with quantitative as well as qualitative metrics. Finally, we looked at edge cases to fine-tune our prediction values between the buckets. Data Cleaning: As mentioned in the question, there were 6 states ('AS','DC', 'GU','MP', 'PR', 'VI') that needed to be deleted from the dataset as they are not considered. This cleaning process was crucial given that these "states" would have materially altered the predictions. Baseline Case: To derive our baseline case, we recreated the positivity rate values used in the study. The values are computed on a 7-day rolling basis, thus we took the last 2 months and computed the 7-day rolling averages. In a second step, to account for the variability in the values, we also computed the 7-day rolling standard deviations for each state specifically. After this, we made the assumption that these each positivity rate value is normally distributed around the mean as of latest available date with a standard deviation computed according to the 7-day rolling window. Given that we have multiple days, we scale the standard deviation accordingly (standard deviation scales with the square root in time).  Finally, to get a probability distribution around the number of states having a positivity rate of over 10.0%, we simulated 1,000,000 paths (with the inputs aforementioned). Benchmark updating: Given that the vast majority of the outcome has already been observed (5 data points of the total 7 data points are already known), we have an elevated threshold for other metrics to alter our hypothesis. First, we considered the fact that the two remaining days are weekends, thus there might be a seasonality effect that might skew the outcome. As already observed in the peak times in major states, there has been a statistically different number of cases on weekends versus weekdays. This is not surprising given that people have more time on the weekends to get tested. However, after having looked at the current data, there seems to be no significant difference between weekends and weekdays, thus we do not need to materially change the assumed underlying distribution. Furthermore, we also tested different underlying distributions to see if those materially change the outcome, but those seemed to have proven robust as well. Last, we parsed through current news to detect any possible testing related issues. Even though, there has been some testing related issues in the past, those have happened long enough to not affect our results materially. Edge cases: Finally, we looked at the edge states. We see that there are currently 10 states (AL, FL, IA, ID, KS, MO, ND, NV, SC, SD) that are above 10.0% positivity rate even if they report both days 1 standard deviation events. Also, even if we look at 1 standard deviation moves both days for the up direction, there are only 5 more additions to the states list, thus limiting the possible outcomes even more to the 11-15 node. However, the up node seems to bear more risk than the down node, thus we adjust our probabilities to be skewed towards more states than less states. Summary: Putting all these perspectives together, we arrive at the probability distribution above.

Summary of the problem: The objective is to assess the number of US states that will report a COVID-19 positivity rate greater than 10.0%.  Positivity rate is the positive cases that have been surfaced from testing: [Positive Cases / Total Tests], rolled on the past 7 days [1].  This data is updated daily and comes from the COVID Tracking Project.  Broad view: I downloaded the data from [2] and computed the time series of the 7 day rolling positivity for each U.S. state. On the last month, the number of US states with more than 10% positivity has an average of 12.1 and a std of 1.3. Week to date, the covid+ has stabilized between 12 and 13.  Sub-Problems Decomposition: Let's examine this question per state with p the probability of a state to have a positivity rate > 0.10 on Sept 1st. I additionally make the hypothesis of the independence of states in term of positivity rates. I categorize the states into 3 buckets: 
- 8 states have a positivity rate > 0.1 + 1std (computed on a 1 month horizon, seems reasonable regarding this rate speed of evolution) and their time series clearly show an upward linear trend -> p = 1
- 32 states have a positivity rate < 0.1 – 1std -> p = 0 
- The remaining 10 states are trickier: AL, AR, AZ, GA, HI, KS, MN, MS, NC, TX. For those names I assign some rough probabilities given the trend of their time series as well as their histogram distributions, giving more value to the near term data (total horizon is again 1 month). As this part of the calculation is kind of arbitrary I chose my probabilities with a 0.1 precision. I then consider each {state i has positivity rate>0.10} to be an independent Bernoulli trial which takes the value 1 with probability p_i. The sum of these random variables is a Poisson binomial distribution. The distribution's mean and variance are intuitive given the independence of the variables mean=5 and variance=0.74. As there is no closed formula for this distribution I run Monte Carlo simulations (100,000). and obtained the following results
11 states: 2%,
12 states: 25%,
13 states: 46%,
14 states: 22%,
15 states: 4%
16 states: 1% Consequently my final forecasts are 99% for 11-15 states and 1% for 16-20%.  Main uncertainty in my model: 
-	I consider the different states to be independent variables.
-	My approach is entirely statistics driven. I did not really look at any fundamental drivers. I do think those kind of questions may worth checking opening schools news etc but with only 2 days of uncertainty ahead it is reasonable to give high weight to the recent data.  [1] https://www.covidexitstrategy.org/definitions-and-criteria
[2] https://covidtracking.com/data

Looking at positiveIncrease and totalTestResultIncrease over the past 7 days we can gain an idea of what to expect in terms of positivity rate. In addition to this, if we note that the eventual metric will be calculated using a 7-day rolling average, we can be quite certain our range will fall between 11 and 15, especially considering the current range is around 13~14.

Summary: take the latest rolling 7-day average, predict whether states with borderline positivity rate will be above 10% based on the assumption that the rolling positivity rate is a random walk with a linear trend.  I first looked at the last available data point on rolling 7-day average positivity rate because we are only two days until the final prediction date. I first calculate the daily standard deviation on this statistic (rolling 7-day positivity rate) in the past 30 days. I choose 30 days as a time frame because recent data is much more relevant in terms of coronavirus outbreak.  I first filter every state that has a rolling positivity rate one standard deviation above 10% on August 28th, which gives me 10 states.  All of these states are well above 10%, and the borderline ones have a upward linear trend. Thus, I am 100% sure that these ten states' rolling 7-day positivity rate will be above 10%. in two days.  I then look at states that are within one standard deviation above the 10% benchmark, which gives me 2 states - AL and KS. Out of the two states, KS has a consistent decreasing trend, which moves around 0.002% every day. It is unlikely KS will have a rate below 10% in two days. AL has been fluctuating. Thus, I assign AL a 50% probability to be above 10% in two days. Now, my prediction is 10.5 states. Finally, I look at states that are within one standard deviation below the 10% benchmark, which gives me 10 states. Assume normality and unchanging mean considering our short time period until the deadline, about 34% of these states will move up one standard deviation.  Now, my prediction is 13.5 states.  Synthesizing the uncertainty and volatility, my final 95% confidence interval is 11.5-15.5, which translate to around 97% "between 11 and 15", 3% "between 16 and 20", and 0% everywhere else.

Currently there are 12 states with a positivity rate > 10% and one (Arkansas) that is at 10.0% flat. The most likely path to 6-10 states appears to be Arkansas, Kansas, and Florida all falling below 10%. Arkansas appears to be a coin flip right now. I would put the probability of Kansas falling below 10.0% at <10% given that its weekly rolling average has remained between approximately 11 and 12.5% for the past two weeks. And similarly, Florida I think also has a sub-10% probability of dipping below 10 given that its positivity rate has been decreasing more or less linearly for the past two weeks at a rate of 0.24 percentage points per day, so it is not on track to go below the 10 mark for another 10.5 days. If we assume these three events are independent we can see that the probability of all three states falling out of the money in the next 2 days is less than 0.5*0.1*0.1 = 0.005. Of course, there are a few other conceivable paths to 6-10: Arkansas+Kansas+Idaho and Arkansas+Kansas+Texas seem about as likely given that Idaho and Texas, while half a percentage point above Florida, have seen more steep declines in their positivity rates recently than Florida has.  I think we can discount the possibility of any state from Missouri on up dipping below 10.0% in the next two days. I think 3.7+ percentage points is too much ground to cover in just 48 hours. Thus, we have 3 roughly equally probable scenarios for the question to settle at 6-10, for a total probability of 1.5%. I think this can be rounded down to 1% as my initial estimates of 10% independently for Kansas/Florida/Idaho/Texas seems a bit generous.  This 1% seems good to keep as there is a small possibility of a data entry error throwing off the stats as well. Similar reasoning as above suggest that the most likely path to 16-20 is for Kansas and 3 or more of (Georgia, Nebraska, Hawaii, Utah, Wisconsin, and Minnesota) to climb above 10% by 9/1. I think very generously the probability of any given one of those states climbing above 10% is 0.15 based on the fact they've all had very flat or slightly downward trending positivity rates for the past two weeks. Using a binomial model with p=.15 and n=6, the probability of any of 3 or more of them reaching above 10 is 0.047. Divided by 2 because of Arkansas gives us a probability of 0.023, or about 2%. I think my conservative-ness on the 15% estimate offsets the fact the states are probably not completely independent and there is some trivial probability of a data entry error. Thus, my prediction is 1% for 6-10, 2% for 16-20, and 97% for 11-15.

I looked at the percent changes in positivity over the past 13 data points and for each state, generated a random sample of 100,000 percent changes from this original data. I used decaying probability weights so that the most recent data was represented more in the sample than older data. Finally I summed over the state samples to obtain a sample of the number of states with a rate greater than 10%. All of this work led to the obvious conclusion that the number in two days is extremely likely to be between 11 and 15 states. I did increase the chances for 6-10 and 16-20 states by 1% each to account for a bit more uncertainty. While my model basically suggested only one of these ranges was possible, it did give some nuance for numbers within that range. Perhaps most interestingly, it gave the highest probability to 13 states, not 12 states (which is the current number). 11 states: 11%
12 states: 34%
13 states: 39%
14 states: 13%
15 states: 2% I think approaching the problem from a completely probabilistic standpoint was justified because I do not understand the dynamics which cause positivity rates to rise and fall. One case where my model might fall apart is if changes in positivity rates are highly correlated across states. I somewhat accounted for this shortfall by adding probability to the tail possibilities.

To obtain this estimate, after reading through the problem statement and linked website, I attempted to understand how the data in the COVID+ RATE IS column was computed. This column did not correspond well with positivity rates found on other well-cited websites, so I focused on replicating the methodology used to compute the focal data column. I did this using the data provided from COVID Tracking Project, which the covidexitstrategy site uses. Currently, there are 13 states which have a positivity rate greater than 10%.  The data is computed over a 7 day rolling average with a several day lag, meaning that today (8/29), several of the datapoints that will be used in the September 1st average are already available. Therefore, my approach forecasted what would happen in remaining days, averaged this with the data for the beginning of the week, and repeated this simulation many times to estimate uncertainty.

Reran simulations and analysis with 8/28/2020 data. No major changes. First I used the data from https://www.covidexitstrategy.org to calculate 7 day rolling positivity (Covid positivity rate). Next I plotted the time series of the number of states with a Covid positivity rate of greater than 10% . It is currently 12 and since August 1st 2020, it has not hit 16 states or higher and it has only hit below 10 states for a brief period of a few days. Using this as a base rate, I next focused on the individual states. I first found the safe states (defined as today's positive rate - one std dev since August 1st, 2020 > 10%). There were 10 such states. Next, I focused on the "iffy" states (those hovering within one std dev of 10% positivity). There were 8 such states (AL, AR, AZ, GA, HI, KS, MN, UT). Based on time series data and trends while accounting for the fact that 4 of the last 7 days have been included in the COVID positivity rate by the time of this prediction, I grouped them into 5 buckets with assigned probabilities that they will go above 10% by the settlement date:  (0.95) Likely >10% = Alabama
(0.75) Lean >10% = Kansas
(0.5) 50/50 = Arkansas, Utah
(0.25) Lean <10% = Hawaii, Minnesota
(0.05) Likely <10% = Arizona, Georgia Finally, I ran a MC simulation with these "coinfip" states with their respective probabilities. I got an EV of 3.228 with a std. error of 0.399. Adding this to the 10 safe states puts the 95% CI squarely between 11 and 15. Finally, I skewed the prediction slightly higher for 11 - 15 bucket. Given the historical trends, I assigned 0 probability to <5 and 6 - 10. Given the CI, I put a slight probability on 16 - 20, no probability on 20+.

Changing my forecast again. There are a solid 10 states that have positivity rates above 12%. There are five states with positivity rates between 9-11%, which could go either way. I think there's a really good chance that there will be between 11 and 15 states with >10% positivity rates.

Formalized my intuition by estimating probabilities that states have over 10%, then ran Monte Carlo simulation using these probabilities. I calculated the standard deviation of each states' 7d rolling positivity rate over the past month. 
Then I formalized probabilities of being above for those states within a standard deviation of the 10% positivity line (assuming those states 1 std dev away would stay on that side): Arkansas, Arizona, Georgia, Hawaii, Kansas,  Minnesota, Nebraska, North Carolina, Utah, Virginia, and South Carolina. This methodology led to a probability distribution that was more skewed than my initial intuitive estimate, while also more concentrated about the mean.
Increased the statewide standard deviation from .2% to .5% and reran MonteCarlo

The opening of schools and universities will create a new spike in cases, despite efforts to maintain distance and contact trace. Those who may have previously been isolated may now be exposed if even one person from a family is going to a school and coming into contact with hundreds of others. Additionally, the CDC release that limits testing to only those with symptoms should increase the COVID+ rate as those with symptoms are more likely to test positive. By September 1, those who contracted the disease as schools first opened should have had enough time to develop symptoms, get tested, and have the results come back. This should keep the rates steady. With 12 states currently above 10%, I think it's possible that a few more reach the threshold. A four state increase seems possible, but unlikely.

After using the current positivity rates for each state gotten from  https://www.covidexitstrategy.org, I ran a Monte Carlo simulation. In each trial, I assumed each state's rate would change by some normally distributed amount, where that error has mean 0 and standard deviation .5%. I also added the same "national error" to every state according to a normal distribution with mean 0 and standard deviation .3%. I got these numbers by looking at a few states' and US' trends over time, and failing to think of any national event that would happen by then that might imply a directional move.
Updated to fix a mistake pointed out by @RSparkes, as the statistics are 7 day moving averages. Leads to more uncertainty in my forecast.

Currently (8/27) there are 12 states above 10%. These are 14 day rolling averages, which helps buffer any extreme changes and effect of noisy reporting periods, and only 4 more days until Sept1. All of these states are above 11.5%, many much higher. Thus base rate estimate of mean is thus 11-15. There are 5 states that are within 1% of the required 10% level; some (such as Georgia) have been trending downwards, while others (such as Utah) trending upwards. Lead me to skew distribution towards higher numbers. Testing amounts are an important factor impacting positivity rate (inversely). Testing amounts seem to have dropped in some of the more heavily affected states (such as FL); hard to attribute to any factor, likely a combination of long wait times and more lax attitude. Some governors may also prefer less tests, since would make case numbers look better (can't test positive if you don't get tested!), but would not believe this to be a major factor. Hard to envision a significant change in the coming days (neither higher nor lower), making me tend more towards the base rate. The second factor is actual infection spread. Likely approx. 1-2w lag between actual infection and positive test; thus must look at mitigation actions taken place in mid August. Hard to envision a massive change in infection spread between today and Sep1, thus cluster distribution even more heavily towards the mean. False positive rate minuscule, likely doesn't contribute much to total positivity rate, and cancels with effect of false negative rate (similarly small). Some uncertainty given the relatively small testing rates in many states, which may lend themselves to some unpredictiveness.

As of 7/9 there are 10 US States with positivity rates greater than 10% with rates ranging from 10.38%-26.81%. There are 5 states with ranges from 8%-10%. Of those 5, 3 have 7 day declining averages or flat(ish). Of the 10 states identified earlier, the ones closest to 10% (10-12%) have increasing 7-day avg numbers. The United States as a whole has been increasing daily since an early low of 4.4% in early June. The trend is negative and therefore unlikely that the current number of 10 can be reduced in the face of growing cases, however, some states are having success which may push neighbors to follow suit so I assigned a meaningful probability to a slight decline (6-10). The states that breach 10% by September 1, 2020 could possibly replace states that exit that bucket, which given the general desire and efforts to help control the oubreak (albeit on a limited basis) I assigned a greater than 50% likelihood. Given the negative case trends, a worsening is certainly possible and I needed to assign a meaningful probability. Anything less than 15% I think would under-represent the chance of occurrence. Lastly, given the state of the pandemic, we have to acknowledge that things could spiral out of control which is why I assigned a 5% chance to 21 or more. I assigned a zero to 5 or fewer because that would require a near extinguishment of the virus from global hotspots. There is nothing that indicates to me that this is possible.
